participants.participant: María García-Legaz Ponce, Head of Investor Relations
César Alierta Izuel, Executive Chairman and Chief Executive Officer
Santiago Fernández Valbuena, Finance and Corporate Development

plist.p: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by and welcome to Telefónica's 2007 full-year results conference call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later we will conduct the question-and-answer session with instructions given at the time. . As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. I would now like to hand over to María García-Legaz, Head of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, madam.
Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to Telefónica's conference call to discuss 2007 full-year results. I am María García-Legaz, Head of Investor Relations.

Before proceeding, let me mention that that this document contains financial information that are reported under IFRS. The financial information contained in this document has been prepared under International Financial Reporting Standards. This financial information is not updated and therefore is subject to potential future modifications. This presentation may contain announcements and that constitute forward-looking statements, which are not guarantees of future performance and involve risks and uncertainties and actual results may differ materially from those in the forward-looking statements, as a result of various factors. We invite you to read the complete disclaimer included in the first page of the presentation, which you will find on our website. We encourage you to review our publicly available disclosure documents filed with the relevant securities market regulators.
If you do not have a copy of the relevant press release and the slides, please contact Telefónica's Investor Relations team in Madrid by dialing the following telephone number, 34-91-482-8700.
Now let me turn the call over to our Chairman, Alierta, who will be leading this conference call.
Thank you, María. Good afternoon ladies and gentlemen and thank you for attending Telefónica's 2007 full-year results conference call.

First let me introduce Santiago Fernández Valbuena, Telefónica's Chief Financial Officer, with whom I will share the review of the Group performance. During the question and answer, you will have the opportunity to ask questions directly to our effective committee. As I have today with me Julio Linares, Chief Operating Officer, Guillermo Ansaldo, Head of Telefónica España; José María Álvarez-Pallete, Head of Telefónica Latinoamérica and Matthew Key, Head of Telefónica Europe.

Before turning to the numbers, I would like to stress that Telefónica equity as current remains very solid, combining the strong fundamentals and high returns. The results we are presenting today, the guidance for 2008 and the announcement of a new share buyback program reinforced our differential profile in the industry. That profile, that shows our strong prior record of execution in a close industry with tangible results. First, we have again delivered on our commitments, meeting or exceeding our ambitious targets for 2007. Second, we continue to out perform our peers, extracting value from our well-diversified asset portfolio, the deeper integration of our operations and our scale. Third, we have materially increased shareholder remuneration rates and dividends in launching a new share buyback program. And finally, we are again set to post very solid results both in 2008 and in the long-term. Let me now review these topics in detail.

Slide number 4 shows the summary of 2007 P&L. Consolidated revenues grew by close to 7% year-on-year to top 56.4 billion euros. In organic terms, sales went up by 7.4% position in Telefónica at the top of the circles in terms of top line settlements.

2007 OIBDA exceeded 22.8 billion euros, up close to 20% or 7% in organic terms, showing the benefit of a scale and higher efficiencies achieved through our integrated management model. Operating income surpassed 17.3 billion euros, equivalent to a 42% nominal growth rate or more than 18% when translated into organic terms. As a proxy to cash flow generation, operating cash flow topped 14.8 billion euros in 2007, up 33% on 2006 figures. Operating cash flow organic growth was 12% in 2007. Forex negative contribution to major financial methods growth stood in the 1.1 to 1.4-percentage point range. In summary, very strong growth rate that is picked up from top to bottom line.
The operating income growth flowed directly into a very solid net income increase as presented in slide number 5.

Net income amounted to 8.9 billion euros in 2007, 43% more than a year ago. Reported earnings per share reached 1.872 euros per share, or 43% annually, while excluding the impact from PPA's earnings per share will reach 2.012 euros. Reported free cash flow percent totaled 1.859 euros in 2007. These figures are totally in line with our organic target of doubling reported earnings per share, a free cash flow percent by 2010 from 2006 levels.

And we continue to deliver on our commitments as we present in slide number 6. I would like to highlight that once again we have met or exceeded our growth targets, target that have been upgraded along the year for the third year in a row. Revenues and OIBDA growth reached the top end of the guidance, while operating income exceeded by four percentage points the high end of the target. CapEx came in line with our estimate of 8.1 billion euros. We believe at the group level, all the business lines meet their respective growth commitments in 2007.

Slide number 7 plots the reconciliation between reported and adjusted for guidance 2007 OIBDA figures. As noted, we are implementing restructuring measures that will increase efficiencies in the future years. The impact of these measures on our numbers, I'll explain in detail in this slide.

Group diversification and subscriber growth, which are key to reliable results are outlined in the slide number 8. Telefónica continues to manage current industry level, capturing new customers, extending their usage patterns through bundled offers across all the markets. In 2007, we had close to 26 million accesses to reach almost 229 million accesses.

Broadband, Pay TV and mobile expansion are the key drivers of customer expansion, posting high double-digit growth rates. In addition, our initiatives to capture more value from our customers are fighting their way with 34% of our total accesses having voice, broadband and TV bundles.

From a regional perspective, Latin America continues to be the main revenue growth engine increasing growth to 13% year in organic terms to account for more than 50% of Telefónica top line expansion. Spain and the rest of Europe represented more than 50% of Group sales and continued to post mid-single organic growth rate. This explains the remarkable 7.4 organic revenue growth at Group level.

Turning to slide number 9, in 2007 Group profitability remained high as we get in a strong hold on costs while driving a strong commercial activity. Organic growth in operating costs was cut by close to two percentage points in 2007 to just 7.2. The low status organic increase due to the high efficiencies achieved. As such, Telefónica OIBDA margin has stood at 75.8, practically flat year-on-year.

Slide number 10, reduced CapEx and operating cash flow generation. 2007 total CapEx reached 8 billion euros in nominal terms with 75% of this figure dedicated to growth and network transformation. A strong CapEx effort is in comparison with high operating cash flow generation enhancing the ratio of our revenues to close to 22%. Operating cash flow grew across all the regions, leading to an 11.8 year-on-year organic increase at the Group level to reach 14.8 billion euros.
And now let me turn the call to Santiago.
Thank you, César. Ladies and gentleman please turn to slide number 11 for a review of our regional business units then we start with Telefónica Span.

Let me first highlight that the fourth quarter has been just another quarter within the 2007 year with a strong commercial activity and revenue growth in line with the first nine months of the year. Business has exceeded all announced targets with revenues growing 4.7% and OIBDA 11.6% on guidance terms in 2007.

This year we have completed the 2003 to 2007 redundancy program in the wireline company with the provision of 229 million euros in the fourth quarter of '07 and we have already launched and started a new program for 2008 as part of the ongoing integration process of the wireline and wireless operations. This has led to an additional provision of 322 million euros in the fourth quarter of '07, which takes the total '07 provision to 667 million euros.

While this charge has reduced OIBDA growth in the short-term, it is paving the way for enhanced efficiency networks in coming years. In respect of this, the 5.6% underlying OIBDA growth in '07 showing the outstanding business performance throughout the year.

Slide number 12 shows the results of the wireline business' commercial strategy focused on upselling towards existing customer base and expanding accesses. Fixed telephony accesses evolution in the fourth quarter was outstanding with positive net adds of 33,000 lines, losing just 0.3% of the lines in 2007. This is our best performance since 2001.

In broadband, we maintained our market share above 56% and reached 4.6 million retail clients or 22% better than a year ago. With the recently launched new products, we are ready to lead the broadband growth opportunity having products targeting all segments, high-end with the 10 to 30 mega connections to be enhanced through 2008 with products based on fiber and VDSL, our reference 3 mega offering, and a range of 1 mega products for the lower segments.

In the Pay TV market, we surpassed half a million clients, increasing our share of the market to just below 13%. This is the resulting in both higher ARPUs, which have gone up 5% to 67 euros and increased revenues.

Turning to slide number 13, revenue growth of 3.7% in Q4 was similar to the first nine months. Traditional access and voice revenues are showing an improved performance, twice the '06 fourth quarter figures. The excellent telephony accesses evolution together with the monthly fee increase are the basis for differential business performance, enhanced with broadband, data and IT growth.

Broadband remained a growth engine at revenue level with over 800,000 retail net adds in '07 and a resulting ARPU at 45 euros. Adding data and IT revenue growth, we get to the 3.7% total growth in revenues exceeding the guidance and standing out among European peers.

In the next slide, slide number 14, we show the almost 15% reported OIBDA growth and how it is affected by the lower provisions related to workforce reductions in '07 versus '06. If you strip out this effect, and you adjust it for one-offs as in 2007, you find among others OIBDA growth stands at 5.1%, showing the sound underlying performance of our businesses.
OIBDA growth exceeded revenue growth by 1.4 percentage points as higher efficiencies have been achieved. According to guidance criteria, OIBDA grew by 15.8%, or at the top end of the guidance.

On slide number 15, we continue with our mobile operations in Spain, which posted very strong commercial results, both in the fourth quarter and for the whole year. 2007, we led the growth of the market, achieving higher net adds than any of our competitors, and sustaining our undisputed leadership. In the fourth quarter alone, our net adds reached 407,000.

The Christmas campaign was very strong, with a different approach versus last year. We moved from short-term traffic promotions to a campaign focused on customer loyalty that will continue paying off in the next few quarters in churn containment.

We focused our efforts on value growth, recording an excellent performance in the postpay segment, with 1.5 million net adds in the year, and contract customers growing over 12% versus December '06, to represent close to 60% of our base. The churn rate has not only been outstanding, but also a differentiating factor, in a year where we have seen the 4th player and 9 MVNOs entering the Spanish market.

On the next slide, we review usage patterns. In 2007, outgoing ARPU remained almost flat, with growth in data ARPU offsetting voice ARPU pressure. Data ARPU growth continued to be driven by the strong increase in connectivity revenue, up 72% on a yearly basis. Cumulative termination rate costs in the year of 14.9% hit incoming ARPU, resulting in a 1.8% decline in total ARPU. more weight in our customer base, it is worth having a look at outgoing ARPU performance excluding these rates, which for the whole of 2007 posted positive growth.
In the last quarter of the year, we led the push on 3G, adding close to 700,000 3G customers, reaching 3.5 million, or 16% of our customer base, up 10 percentage points versus December '06.

In slide number 17, we show that we have met our guidance in terms of both service revenue and we have exceeded the OIBDA targets. Service revenues increased by a healthy 4.2% over 2006 on comparable terms, and retained by the strong 6.5 advance – the 6.5% advance in customer revenue, fully backed by the customer base growth. Incoming revenues, including both interconnection and roaming-in, declined year-on-year due to lower prices.

Regarding profitability, a 154 million euros provision has been recorded in Q4, leading to a 2.8% growth year-on-year. Excluding these one-offs, OIBDA would have grown 6.5% ahead of the committed 4 to 5% guidance and expanding margins on good – on the good quality of revenues.

In next slide, you have the reconciliation of how to get from the 2007 reported OIBDA to 2007 OIBDA for guidance comparison, should you want to check those numbers out for yourselves and verify that we have fully delivered.

Let me now start and, to go through the review for Latin American properties on slide number 19. The commercial activity in the region remains very strong. Mobile penetration surpassed the 70% mark in December of '07 and over 12 percentage points increase in the last year.

In the fourth quarter of '07, we achieved record mobile net adds of close to 7.3 million, up 61% year-on-year. Customer growth accelerated to increase by almost 17% versus December '06 and surpassed the 134 million accesses mark, driven by wireline, broadband and mobile services. This strong operating performance led to a solid revenue evolution that increased 11% year-on-year in current euros, on the back of favorable 6% mobile ARPU increase in the year or well ahead of the indication given in London.
Reported OIBDA expanded by 8.4%, impacted by personnel reorganization that reached close to 320 million euros in 2007. Excluding this charge, OIBDA would have increased by 11.8%.

Operating cash flow in the year almost reached 3.8 billion euros, with positive cash flow generation in all the countries, except Mexico. Revenues and OIBDA performance across the different countries are shown on slide number 20.

The top line performance has been robust along the year in most of the countries where we operate, reaping the benefits of our business diversification. Regarding operating income before D&A, please take into account the personnel reorganization programs in place, as their reported OIBDA growth figures of the integrated operators are impacted.
All countries show the positive performance with the exception of Brazil, where the bad debt provision and the new revenue stream with lower margin are hitting the profitability.

Let me now share with you how we are accelerating the transformation of our wireline operations in slide number 21. In the fourth quarter of '07, broadband net adds reached 332,000 or up 19% year-on-year. Total retail broadband connections surpassed the 5 million mark in 2007 for a 33.2% increase on an annual basis. This progress on broadband development is a key to our strategy, both fostering bundles and increasing broadband speed to enhance the use of our value-added services.

Growth in Pay TV was even higher at this last quarter of the year. Net adds were over three times those of the fourth quarter of '06, partially due to the incorporation of TVA customers. Pay TV is enabling us to offer triple play solutions, key tools to limit the pressure on the traditional baseline business.
Let me also highlight the strong increase in bundles, which already represent 53% of our fixed accesses, 15 percentage points better than 2006.

Let me now review our mobile operations here in Brazil in slide number 22. Vivo's performance in the last quarter of the year has been robust in a highly competitive market. Vivo leveraged its highly quality network – its high quality networks, commercial channels and store brand awareness to increase gross adds by 66% in the first quarter of '07, 83% of them in GSM. Churn continues to go down to reach 2.1% in the fourth quarter, allowing to increase last year fourth quarter net adds by 6.6 times. In 2007, Vivo grew its customer base by 15%, topping 33.5 million.

ARPU evolution was also outstanding, up 14.5% year-on-year, or 6.6% if we exclude the B&K effect. This brilliant operating performance translates into an 18% growth in service revenue on the back of outgoing service revenues that accelerated their growth rate in the last quarter of the year. Revenue growth, coupled with strict control measures, resulted in a 30.8% OIBDA growth, on a like-for-like basis, expanding margins by almost 3 percentage points.

Now on slide number 23, we continue with our Mexican operations. Fourth quarter commercial results have been very strong on the back of new innovative and competitive products. Gross adds in the last quarter of the year increased 31% to reach 2.3 million.
Churn continued its positive performance against the market trend and came down year-on-year to a standard 2.5%, driving net adds up by 32%.

In 2007, we gained close to four million customers, expanding our customer base by 47% to surpass the 4.5 million mark. Let me remark, the good performance of churn on a yearly basis that allowed us to cost lead a 43% increase in gross adds in the year include an 82% advance in net adds.

Our usage patterns continue their strong momentum. In 2007, minutes of use soared by close to 80%, leading to a 16% ARPU increase, a very positive trend in the Mexican market. This robust operating performance drove outgoing service revenues up by 82%. Despite the strong commercial activity, 2007 OIBDA reached 179 million euros, a 12.5% margin versus the negative figures registered in 2006. Operating cash flow improved significantly in 2007 from minus 191 million euros to minus 51 million euros, though it is still impacted by the stronger investment efforts made in 2007.

And in the next slide, we review our other Latin American mobile operations. In Argentina, Venezuela, Uruguay, and Colombia, outgoing service revenue growth in 2007 outpaced customer growth. Let me highlight Colombian performance, where fourth quarter outgoing revenue growth excelled the usual performance. This strong revenue growth combined with efficiency advances led to margin expansion. Peru's commercial activity has been very strong, leading to the highest customer growth in the group. Revenues in OIBDA grew steadily, though margin was diluted due to the high commercial activity.

In Chile, the most mature market in the region, we achieved strong ARPU advances that lead to a 23% growth in outgoing service revenue. To finish with Ecuador, where the turnaround of operations is showing up, usage is increasing, leading to 16% increase in fourth quarter outgoing service revenue versus the minus 1% growth recorded in the first nine months of the year. Therefore, for the whole year 2007 service revenue remained flat.

Let's now move to Europe starting with slide number 25. Revenues went up by 9.9% year-over-year to almost 14.5 billion euros. Excluding Airwave, revenue growth was 11.7%, in line with guidance. OIBDA reached almost 5 billion euros, including the gain from the disposal of Airwave. Excluding personnel reorganization and other non-foreseeable charges, OIBDA would be around 4 billion, representing growth of over 10% at the top end of guidance.

Personnel reorganization implemented across the group during the year forced the cancellation of the T-Mobile national roaming agreement as we accelerated the build out of our network gave rise to a one-off charge of 338 million euros in 2007.
CapEx was below guidance and fell almost 17% year-on-year due to the exclusion of Airwave and 2007 CapEx brought forward into 2006 for O2 Germany's 3G network rollout.

Turning to slide number 26, the U.K. business continued to outgrow the market and both customer and ARPU growth were behind the 18.6% rise in total revenues in 2007, above the top end of our guidance. O2 U.K. ended the year leading the market with 18.4 million mobile subscribers, up 4.2% on an annual basis. The contract customer base grew to 37% of the total base by the end of the year, an increase of 1.8 percentage points driven by good gross adds and continued improvement in churn.

During the year, 79% of total net additions were on contract. The iPhone helped to deliver record net connections of contract customers in the fourth quarter. On-net ARPU went up by 4.4% in the fourth quarter with positive evolution of both usage and data ARPU, growing by 9.8% and 9.1% respectively. Non-SMS data revenues are growing at over 40%.

Growth in OIBDA was 1%, but excluding personnel reorganization charges, growth was 10.6% and fully in line with guidance. OIBDA margin showed a steady increase over the year as expected, reaching 26.4% for the full year, excluding personnel reorganization charges.

And now in slide number 27, we present O2 Germany's result. From an operating standpoint, O2 Germany has successfully focused on growing its convert customer net editions with 756,000 customers added in 2007, representing 48% growth over 2006. The total customer base ended the year at 12.5 million customers, up 13.1% versus '06. This included the reduction of 310,000 in the prepaid segments after a review of revenue generating customers. Our Chivo mobile base continues to grow well, now with 1.2 million customers. The Fonic brand launched in September, has already grown to 200,000 customers. Regarding in units and mail tariffs, more than 2.14 million customers have already signed up.

Telefónica Deutschland grew its unbundled plans by a factor of 3.5% to reach 671,000 in 2007. O2 DSL is beginning to gain traction with 75,000 customers at the end of the year and a strong order book. The trend in revenues improved during the year with fourth quarter revenues flat year on year.

Revenue growth in 2007 was 6.7%, slightly under guidance criteria. With continued mobile customer growth during 2007 and a re-balancing of the mobile tariff portfolio underway, along with the growing DSL wholesale business and a strong order book for O2 DSL going to 2008, O2 Germany will return to growth in 2008. 2007, OIBDA was 473 million euros impacted by personnel reorganization and the charge for cancellation of the national roaming contract with T Mobile among others. Excluding these charges and under guidance criteria, OIBDA grew 23.8% towards the top end of guidance.

In the Czech Republic in slide number 28, the business continues to grow at a healthy rate of 3% at the top end of revenue guidance, driven mainly by the mobile business but also helped by growing broadband revenues in the fixed business offsetting the decline in traditional access and voice revenues.
The trend in line loss is encouraging, helped by a growth in broadband connections, driven by speed upgrades and bundled offers with 100,000 customers now taking the bundle.
O2 TV customers exceeded 73,000 at the end of the year with a 25% increase in retail broadband connections.

In mobile, the proportion of contract customers in the base continues to grow, now at 43.8% with bundled quarterly ARPU increasing by 2.2% year on year, driven by both increased usage and the changing customer mix.

OIBDA was fully in line with guidance with the year-on-year decline mainly due to costs associated with the Slovak businesses, which reduced OBIDA margins by around two points as expected. OIBDA margin for the year was only 1.1 percentage point lower than in 2006 due to efficiency savings and re-branding costs booked in 2006. The Slovak business reached 565,000 registered customers at the end of the year. Due to the high level of double SIM cards in the market, inactivity levels remain high.

And now, please move to slide 29 for a quick update on group synergies. All initiatives to further integrate operations are running on track. Yield in synergies up more than 1.6 billion euros in 2007, well above the target that we had committed for this year. Close to half of our 2007 target comes from regional management mainly related to our focus on the group commercial approach actions as well as the integration of network operations, processes, and IT. Global initiatives to extract benefits of scale add close to 40% of the total synergies. By geographies, around 69% of 2007 synergies have been generated in Latin America where regional management has been developed since 2004.

And now on slide 30, we turn to show our financial profile which has been stable in the middle of the financial turmoil of the latter half of 2007. Interest expense reached 2.8 billion euros in 2007 which on 50.8 billion euros, total average debt provides an effective cost of servicing debt of 5.59%. Close to one-third of the increase is due to a high percentage of debt denominated in Latin American currencies and close to two-thirds of the increase, or 32 basis points, are due to higher short-term interest rates in Europe. In the fourth quarter, the FX breakdown for liabilities remained broadly stable.

On the bottom left chart of this page, we would like to highlight our maturity profile, which is especially relevant in the current market conditions. Telefónica has no need to access capital markets in the near future, as we can rely on our free cash flow generation and our unused credit facilities of almost 10 billion euros or more than 50% of which are long-term. An additional strong point is that our average debt life is 6.3 years, thus, longer than the time needed for full repayment if all available free cash flow was dedicated to this goal.

We have visited all major bull markets in 2007, in benchmark size, and we have opened the new Czech and Japanese markets. Most of the funds raised in 2007 were applied to smooth out our maturity profile in years '08, '09 and 2010, to allow us to show current comfortable maturities and avoid dependence on volatile current markets. Another sign of our healthy position is the rolling over of our 2 billion euro Commercial Paper program throughout the whole 2007 and the first months of 2008, at spreads very close to zero.

Please turn now to slide 31, for a comment on our de-leveraging progress. Please note how Telefónica has been able to upgrade shareholder remuneration to 5.2 billion euros, and de-leverage by 7 billion euros at the same time. As of December, our net financial debt stands at 2.3 times OIBDA, excluding extraordinary results from divestments, significantly below our 2006 figure, as a consequence of our net debt reduction and OIBDA growth. Net debt plus cash commitments is within the leverage target range of two to two-and-a-half that we set last October in our London Investor Day.

Financial debt has been cut by almost 7 billion euros, driven mainly by first, a 3.7 billion euros free cash flow, retained after shareholder remuneration; second, 2.5 billion euros net divestments and third; 0.8 billion euros of foreign exchange savings, thanks to foreign exchange liability management. And now, let me turn back the call over to our chairman.

Thank you, Santiago. Now, I would like to run you through our 2008 guidance. In the slide number 32, once again, Telefónica sets benchmark in the industry, both in terms of the stability and growth prospect. We have a very positive outlook for this year. With solid 2008 targets being totally in line with our long-term guidance provided in London four months ago. We expect top line growth to grow between 6 and 8%. We anticipate operating income before depreciation and amortization to go up by 7.5 to 11%. Growth in operating income is expected to reach 13 to 19%.

Total CapEx will be around 8.6 billion euros in 2008. The increase in CapEx in 2008 is mainly driven by initiatives to foster top line growth. CapEx in Latin America will be above 2007 figure due to the higher than initially expected customer growth. The strong traffic increase in wireless 2.5 and 3G networks in key markets to further expand our programs and basic Pay TV services.

In Spain, we will continue to invest in growth and transformation, expanding our broadband networks both in wireline and wireless. In Europe, we are accelerating the network build in Germany, providing the business with a strong product line to capture the significant growth opportunities in this country with a 3.5 billion euros CapEx plan for 2007, 2010. At the same time, we will further develop our fixed broadband networks both in the U.K. and in Germany.

In October, we anticipate the total CapEx of less than 36 billion euros for 2007, 2010 period. But we do not think that the spending will be linear. We are maintaining our guidance 2008 to mark the peak in the CapEx deceleration and total CapEx in 2009 and 2010 will be in the range of 8 billion euros per year.

Leveraging our well diversified for portfolio of assets and geographies we are expecting above average sector growth rate across our business in 2008. In Spain, we expect Telefónica España to post very robust results. Fixed broadband in wireless markets should be lower than in 2007. So broadband wireless growth will be higher.

We are expecting sales to grow between 2 and 3.5% while OIBDA growth will be in the 6 to 8% range. This performance remarks our differential growth profile versus all the incumbent players in Europe. Please notice that from 2008, the business model applicable to most telephony services hasn't changed due to the new regulatory framework. Thus, only the net margin on the business will be recorded as revenues. To facilitate like-for-like comparisons, 2000 revenues adjusted for guidance are considered in these changes. I would like to stress that this change did not have a meaningful effect on EBITDA neither an impact in our long-term revenue guidance.

In Europe, we will advance in our strategy to capture growth opportunities and build a bigger business for the future. This translates into a revenue growth in the 4 to 7% range, while OIBDA is expected to grow between 2 to 6%.

In Germany, we will accelerate our growth in both mobile and DSL markets, which will clearly have a cost. We think this is the right thing to do in order to build towards our targets of significant market share gains in the mobile and a higher DSL customer base by 2010. We want to create a scaled business and capture the opportunities in this market.
On the other hand, the wholesale DSL business has only just broken even at the OIBDA level on a monthly basis. Therefore, first year contributions to OIBDA will be weighted towards 2009 and 2010.

In the U.K., we will capture growth and build our DSL base. Our DSL offer has had very positive customer feedbacks, and we will have a more aggressive push in the market to begin building towards our 2008 target of 1 million customers. At the same time, we will continue to grow the mobile market in 2008. We see an opportunity to take more growth and share in post-paid as solid competitors falter. This will lead to a more valuable business and share growth for post-paid ARPU, but we want to improve our position in the market.

In Latin America, we aim to capture a significant part of the untapped growth potential in wireless and broadband penetrations, forcing bundles and accelerating the transformation of wireline operations. This will allow revenues to grow between 11 to 14%, while the larger scale of operations and the focus on efficiency will lead of EBITDA growth to stand between 12 and 15%.
Turning to the next slide, in context of different rumors every day, we are not only presenting a very robust guidance for 2008, but confirming our long term target.

Slide number 34 shows how we are fully on track to meet the guidance we provided in our last investors conference in October. If you add to the 2007 actual growth rate, our forecast for 2008, you can see that meeting 2010 targets does not imply that we will have to outperform.

I will now explain slide 35 which includes a guide how 2008 targets have been calculated, that you can review in detail later on. Our solid growth prospects are accompanied by an enhanced shareholder remuneration policy as we present in slide 36. In the year 2007, we have distributed to shareholders close to 5.2 billion euros; combining dividends and buybacks equivalent to a 5% cash yield.

Yesterday, we announced a new 100 million share buyback program which will run until mid 2009. We will reset the start of the program to the first of January of this year and its complete execution is sensitive to the cash flow generation and share price evolution. This new share buyback program, jointly with the recently increased dividend for 2008 to 1 euro per share represents a very attractive remuneration policy.

To sum up, a robust performance in 2007, a confirmation of our track record for delivering our commitments and the solid guidance for 2008 reinforces our differential profile in the industry. Despite market concerns due to market uncertainties, our fundamentals remain intact. And the underlying performance of our business is very robust. Commercial momentum continues across countries and business, fostering top-line growth, while benefiting from our integrated strategy and skill in the diversification derives in further efficiency gains. As a result, we retain benchmark growth rates from top to the bottom. Shareholder remuneration comes first, our strong free cash flow generation allow us not only to increase dividends but to announce a new share buyback program offering very attractive shareholder returns.

We hope that 2007 results, 2008 guidance and the new share buyback program released today increase your confidence in our company and alleviate your concerns about the growth prospect. The rest about Telefónica has not changed since we met in October.
Thank you very much and now we are all ready to take your questions.
Thank you sir. The first question comes from the line of Luis Prota. Please go ahead announcing your company name and location.

Yes, hello. This is Luis Prota, Morgan Stanley from Madrid. I have two questions. The first one is on fixed telephone in Spain and what are the risks behind the PSTN growth in the fourth quarter of 33,000 lines, whether it's because the market has been growing or you are taking share or campaigns for free connection? What are the reasons behind?

And the second question is on the impact that you are foreseeing from any potential economic slowdown in Spain in terms of line loss but also ARPUs and DSL, voice traffic and overall for the group. Thank you.

Thank you, Luis. This is Guillermo Ansaldo. First, the positive net gain that we saw in the last quarter of last year in fixed wireline in the PSTN we believe it's an exceptional result and should not be extrapolated into the future. I think it was a coincidence of us having two free of charge installation campaigns during that quarter and maybe the competition was not that agile during that quarter. The market as a whole according to our estimation grew by almost 2% during the last year.
Regarding your second questions, our guidelines for 2008 take into account our best information and estimates for the whole year as of today. So we feel very comfortable with those numbers.
Okay. Thank you.
Next question please.
The next question comes from the line of Terence Sinclair. Please go ahead with your question announcing your company name and location.

Hello, this is Terry Sinclair from Citi. Two questions. First of all, you make provisions for personnel restructuring often. I understand that the Spanish process is now concluded, but could you just confirm that? What further personnel reductions are you expecting, for example in Latin America, over the next couple of years? To what extent are these actually recurring rather than non-recurring items?

Secondly, could we just talk a little bit about your expectations for German margin recovery beyond '08?
